text: OPEN CLOSE on the most medieval face youвЂ™ve ever seen: pale, injured, vengeful face, capable of a routine mask o piety: a PRIEST. With a dirty fingernail the Priest flick out part of a frozen worm from a winter apple. We are at INTERSECTION of two lanes of near-frozen mud in HEDGEROW COUNTRY. Two GRAVEDIGGERS, a cold PRIEST, a BODY, At a CROSSROADS overlooked by a Celtic cross. ON SOUND, as the Priest contemplates his meal (He wants better and is sure he deserves it) we hear...the PICK AND SPADE at work, digging the grave at the EXACT CENTER of t CROSSROADS.
(singing) I am Francois, to my dismay (the SPADE digs into the nearly frozen ground) Conceived and born in the usual way... (throws earth) Son of man, yet by the way/ not of him my mother say...

(beyond cold in thin and ragged wool) Shut up and dig. Chewing his apple he stares at: A SMALL BODY, wrapped in something like burlap. Where the wrapping is parted we se pitiful WHITE FACE and OPEN EYES upon which snowflakes fa A rope-scarred neck. A WOMAN: A SUICIDE. A SILVER CRUCIFIX around her neck. The PRIEST, eyeing the crucifix, is for a moment unable t eat his apple. Then he eats. (CONTINUED)
The GRAVEDIGGERS are in rags, dirty, coughing. The GRAVEDIGGER is cleverer than his condition, watching for opportunity in life long after he should have stopped looking. His right ear is mutilated.

(dangerously clever) Denied the cross for suicide, the suicide is then buried at the center of a cross. (leans on his pick, like a scholar) Show me the logic. (a noticeable beat) Father. (digs, then:) Father...
What.
The Devil is a practical man. If this be a witch there was poor return on his investments.
What would you know of Logic?
(the rising, and vindictive, Common Man) I have ears, Father. Though one is notched because I love justice.
Thieving. (thieving, he puts the dead womanвЂ™s CRUCIFIX around his own neck.) Dig. The GRAVEDIGGER (a man who will come into his own, has vo it), digs.

When I was young and so the world/I was as pretty as a girl/I am now a man of gravitas/With a double chin and giant arse... The PRIEST suddenly (as RAVENS erupt from trees beyond a frozen field) looks in the direction away from the sunris (CONTINUED)

(at the GRAVEDIGGERS, ceasing to dig, also stare) Horses. (softly, querulously, and as if thereвЂ™s an opportunity in it) Knights. Straightens his clothes. Medievally speaking, th eboss is coming. A PART OF MOUNTED KNIGHTS AND MEN-AT-ARMS come along the road. They are cloaked, cowled. The colors of their cloth are the only color in the day. The KNIGHTS ride mares, bu ready-saddled DESTRIERS are led behind the party, which a is accompanied by a CART. A SQUIRE rides before, in rich, dirty velvet (the livery of IBELIN.) The SQUIRE, who has cold, and is none too happy at the French weather, comes on a mudd palfrey, and looks at the gravediggers, the bod suicide being buried at a crossroads? Normal. The PRIEST low.

(flatly, no conceit) Clear the road. As the sound of horses draw nearer the PRIEST and the GRAVEDIGGERS back out of the road and bow, giving the roa to: THE TRAVELLERS. A scowling, huge, German knight (ODO), a worldly and scholarly HOSPITALER, and ENGLISH SERGEANT (n knight but mounted to fight as one despite inferior armor black mercenary (FIRUZ), and two MOUNTED GENOESE CROSSBOW in leather armor. The principal of the party is GODFREY O IBELIN. Godfrey is what in those days might pass for a vi sixty, battle-scarred. He wears beneath his cloak (as do knights) armor modified by use in the desert, padded and quilted in the Saracen manner. GODFREY is a man riding in his past. He seems to remember the crossroads, the countryside-- but not with any joy. He seems a man with a heavy obligation on his mind. He stares down at the body. The PRIEST (standing, head bowed, with the gravediggers a the knights pass) is in a frenzy of curiosity but does no dare look up as GODFREY passes. THE HOOVES OF DESTRIERS, PALFREYS, MULES, pass by the small body and the just-fini grave. the PRIEST stays with eyes averted until the rides (and their creaking cart) have passed. (CONTINUED)

(to the other gravedigger) Crusaders. (a beat) I can smell the blood and spices. (resentfully beginning to dig) I can smell the opportunity. The second GRAVEDIGGER does not agree about вЂњopportunit Where he is now is where he will die. He digs. THE SQUIRE who has turned back, reins in. He tosses a coin.
For this burial, from my lord. And amass for the soul. The priest bows greasily but he has other uses for the co

GODFREY, riding, stares around at the wintry countryside his youth. His face is intelligent, lined, grave, scarred: he has se the world to its very end and now he has returned to wher was born. He sees: AN ORCHARD. It smokes with frost. (Perhaps there is a particularly memorable tree). He looks then at: A prosper strong, thatched farm with a workshop building (a FORGE); it is still. No smoke rises from the chimneys. A grubby APPRENTICE (his job, of which he is certainly incapable, to defend the farm in its ownerвЂ™s absence) s out at the passing nights from behind a hedge. The HOSPIT looks curiously at Godfrey, who is staring towards the fo
You know this place, my lord?
I know all of it. He spurs on. The TRAVELLERS continue towards... THE LOCAL CASTLE.
The PRIEST is staring after the knights with interest, fe speculation. The workmen begin to throw the body into the finished grave.
You've forgotten. An AXE falls to the frozen ground. The GRAVEDIGGERS look each other.
She was your brother's wife.
She was a suicide. Cut off her head. (hurries away) And return the axe! The PRIEST hurries after the KNIGHTS. White ambitious fac

head_text.subj: EXT. THE VILLAGE. LATER THAT MORNING

text: A cloister is being added to an existing town church. The local BISHOP, fat, shrewd, a politician, but fundamentall decent man, anxiously watches the progress, the PRIEST wi hm, both clerics holding up their skirts from the mud.
Your brother. You have spoken to him?
(mock-concerned) He is insane with grief, my lord, and still arrested.
The burial was...
Yes.
Yet you did not mutilate the person.
(lying piously) No. (CONTINUED)

A law can go too far. (chewing a thumbnail) It can go too far. I ask myself вЂњWould Jesus do it thusly?вЂќ There is so much done in Christendom of which Christ would not be capable. One day we must look into it. (walking) You must release your brother. I cannot do without him.
My brother, my lord Bishop, is possessed by the Devil, and must be... (with relish) examined.

Talk of the Devil much more and I shall begin to wonder how well you know him. (moving on) Your brother is as mad as I am. He grieves. (a beat) Without your brother I cannot finish the church. Let him out. (as the PRIEST, thwarted, submits to this, the BISHOP digs in his robes) Give him this (a chinking fat, PURSE) and tell him...that he is at the very center of my praters. PRIEST is unhappy, but takes the PURSE, and complies. He off down the muddy street. Turning a corner, he quickly shakes out half the money into his own purse. Then more t half.

location: THE YARD OF THE FORGE. DISCONTINUOUS

text: A splendid rooster, Chanticleer, taking a dust-bath. A womanвЂ™s BARE FEET move through the farmyard. The face o woman we have seen dead. She is alive, smiling. She is kneeling at the edge of a kitchen garden, planting small saplings, a LOMBARDY POPLAR, smiling back at her observer BALIAN, in sunlight, on the best day of his life. Face dripping. He is at the trough, washing. (CONTINUED)
EGGS are laid in a bed of grasses. The WIFE looks back at observer. (Balian), walks through a door, and disappears.

BALIAN awakes in reality and in dirty straw. He sits up. is no more than thirty as it was in those days. Nothing i his face except the fact that he has again remembered his wife is dead. Balian is no peasant. He is a master crafts a blacksmith and inventor. He is watched by two sympathet GUARDS. The PRIEST, entering, has no fear of Balian: he has been tormenting him for years, and knows him as an easy target man who will never strike back.

(resentfully) The Bishop needs you. (as Balian says nothing) Release him. He goes, a man off on his business. BALIAN remains sittin the straw. He stares at the open DOOR as if not knowing w to do with such a thing as a door.
(to Balian, kindly) On your feet. This is not heaven. It is the world, and there are troubles in it. Do yourself no injury. Other men are always good for that. BALIAN nods, and does stand.

A whimpering DOG scratches at the forzen ground, already covered with snow. The burial crossroads. BALIAN, drunk, looking at the stars. Then he falls to his knees, staring the earth. He touches the ground. It is frozen and his wi is beneath it. As he sobers up,
THE PRIEST comes along, with BOYS and GRAVEDIGGER carryin bundles of fuel and torches. (CONTINUED)

BALIAN continues to kneel. The burden-carriers walk on, crossing themselves, in semi-respectful silence (though o of the BOYS laughs, and is swatted by the GRAVEDIGGER). T PRIEST remains behind, and crouches by his brother.
You must take the corss. Crusade. BALIAN, in an extremity of grief, has nothing to say to t

Her grave was here. Or was it there. I am afraid I cannot tell you the exact location. I wasnвЂ™t present at the burial. (BALIAN stares at the ground) Call me a liar. You have reason. (a beat) You never fight back. (slaps BalianвЂ™s face aside) You turn the other cheek. Do you think you are Jesus Christ? (BALIAN simply looks at him, snowflakes in his lashes. ) I think that you conceive yourself without sin. That is a sin. BALIAN gets up and walks away through the snow. The PRIES stares after him.

head_text.subj: INT. THE GREAT HALL OF THE CASTLE. NIGHT

text: MUSIC. The travellers from the Holy Land, employing their knives, are dining with GODFREY'вЂ™S BROTHER (who stayed provincial lord while his brother became a baron in the H Land). GODFREY is self-absorbed, thinking, eating reflectively. The HOSPITALER carries the conversation wit the GODFREYвЂ™S BROTHER and the brotherвЂ™s mendacious, c and worthless SON (GodfreyвЂ™s nephew), who is drinking a his guts are on fire. GODFREYвЂ™S BROTHER And what of Jerusalem?
(suavely) In peril, my lord. As always. (CONTINUED)
GODFREYвЂ™S BROTHER We have stood there against the Saracens for almost a hundred year.

The Saracens, as you call them, have now unified in Egypt, Syria and all Arabia. (a beat) The Saracens have someone... (another suave beat) new. GODFREYвЂ™S NEPHEW (follows the Crusades like sports) Saladin. Their king.
Yes. Salah Ad-din. GODFREYвЂ™S BROTHER (belches ) Gibberish. The Hospitaler smiles mildly, holds up an ornate silver w cup, and to change the subject:

Very fine. GODFREYвЂ™S NEPHEW (picking a fight he couldnвЂ™t win) Do you mean, Hospitaler, that it is very fine for such a poor place? ODO, the German knight, looks up at, with relish, a poten enemy. Odo loves an enemy. The HOSPITALER is suave.

I mean that it is very fine. GODFREYвЂ™S BROTHER And yet you do not drink. A knight should be a knight, a monk a monk, not both at once, that is what I say. (The Hospitaler mildly ignores this.) But I am old-fashioned. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
GODFREYвЂ™'S BROTHER (CONT'D) As for the cup, I have an artificer. A blacksmith. Or did have...

(distracted, staring away) Which son of the blacksmith of my time is the blacksmith now? GODFREYвЂ™S BROTHER The eldest. Balian. (as GODFREY after a beat resumes eating) His child died. His wife fell into a melancholy. She would not listen to reason. She killed herself. (disinterested, worldly) It occurs. But whatвЂ™s that to you?

A private matter. GODFREYвЂ™S BROTHER is thick and incurious. Eats. GODFREY drinking wine, moves to a window and parts the ragged hangings to look, with thoughtful sadness, down into the valley. GODFREYвЂ™S BROTHER (drunk, and disguising bitterness) It is six and twenty years since my brother took the cross, and now he returns an actual Baron of the Kingdom of Jerusalem. How is that for the lot of a younger brother? In his rude hall in his rude castle (as KNIGHTS drink to GODFREY), he laughs and toasts, and murmurs to his SON (Godfrey's nephew, who leans towards him): GODFREYвЂ™S BROTHER (CONT'D) (sotto voce) With no heir it comes to me and thus to you. GODFREYвЂ™S NEPHEW (a sadistic fop, a raper of goose-girls) Then I thank my stars for my uncle. (CONTINUED)
ll.

GODFREYвЂ™S POV We see the lights of the village. Perhaps even at this distance we can see the glow of the forge. SNOW is fallin SNOW blows into the room. Godfrey, cold, reflective, coug slightly, drops the drapery.

BALIAN sits up in his wifeless bed in the darkened loft. Breaks ice in a stone bowl. Throws water into his face. G on into the main living area. A rope still hangs from a rafter. Balian cuts it down. A CRADLE, finely made, stand the middle of the room. Balian puts it in the fire. A boy (BalianвЂ™s APPRENTICE) stares at his master.

We shall go to work. EXT/INT. BALIANвЂ™S FORGE. LATER THAT MORNING Smoke rises. An ANGLE-IRON plunged to cool in a barrel of water. Then thrown with a clang with others on a heap. BALIAN emerges from the forge, and throws ironwork (angle irons, simple braces, presumably for building the church) into a cart. He looks up (startled) and sees: GODFREYвЂ™S SQUIRE, sitting a palfrey.
yOu are the blacksmith? (BALIAN nods) Balian the eldest son of the Balian that was? BALIAN nods.

(as he turns his horse) Remain. The SQUIRE, after another strange, direct look at Balian, rides off. INT. BALIANвЂ™S FORGE. LATER BALIAN is eating coarse brown bread, and staring at the APPRENTICE. The two eat together silently. On SOUND we he horses.  12.
BALIAN walks out into the light. The entire party stares him. The Knights, the English Sergeant, FIRUZ, the two Crossbowmen, and Godfrey.
(pointing) That is the man. ODO, riding, ducking low in the saddle, peers into the fo as if (characteristically) looking for stealables.
You are an armorer. An artificer. According to your lord, and this priest. Have you a woman here? The PRIEST kicks at his small donkey, riding around the y
There is no wife. Yet the matter of women does dangle about the place.

(dismounting) You have my sympathy and blessing and your wifeвЂ™s soul is today the object of my prayers. BALIAN bows his head. GODFREY watches through the snow. HOSPITALER (CONTвЂ™D) We need the horses shod. All. And by asking about a woman he means that we need food and will pay.
The TRAVELLERS are lolling in the think sunlight, eating chicken beneath a tree. The hungry PRIEST has not been invited to eat but is still attempting to ingratiate hims

He has made great engines for sieges. He has made war machines to cast the largest stones...he works finely in silver...He would be one of the few on your journey worth more alive than dead. (CONTINUED)

(eating) Shut up. GODFREY is not listening. His wine cup shakes slightly in hand. GODFREY, of all things, is nervous He walks across the ro into the orchard. In a FLASH of summer we see a dark-hair woman retreating from him, a complex look of fear and, ju possibly, invitation. GODFREY drinks. The HOSPITALER seems to understand what Godfrey is thinking: and well he should, because he is Godfrey's confessor.
Do you still advise what you advised upon the road?
I do, my lord. But I take no credit for your contrition. I am merely your confessor. (concerned for the shivering Godfrey) It is warm by the forge.

BALIAN, assisted by the Italian Crossbowmen and the ENGLI SERGEANT, is shoeing a DESTRIER. The huge war horse has h to be roped against the side of the stall. BALIAN calms h talking to him. BALIAN finishes the last shoe, steps back ODO is there, eating an apple.
(to Balian) Have you been at war? BALIAN nods. He tries to go back to work.
(coming close) An archer, putting arrows in your betters?
On horse. And as an enginer, also. The entering GODFREY is now in earshot. He looks at Balia (CONTINUED)
Against whom and for whom did you fight?

For one Lord against another, on a point which cannot be remembered, and which is then or now had no significance. The PRIEST, looking through a window, listens outraged at brotherвЂ™s outspoken reply. ODO grins.
(close to Balian) There is better game now. One God against another. The pay is proportionate. ODO menaces BALIAN with sword. BALIAN looks at the point, then u at ODO. Laughter.

(piously opportunistic) I have been telling him that. opO, still eating his apple, sees: a LATIN PHRASE CUT DEE INTO A BLACKENED BEAM (or painted, like a frieze, onto th plaster). He points with the sword.
What does that say?
вЂњWhat man is a man who does not make the world better.вЂќ The HOSPITALER smiles, walking: he is beginning to know t man.
My father cut it there. The HOSPITALER looks at Godfrey. GODFREY stands, to his d
Leave me with this man. The room empties as if GodfreyвЂ™s voice is a starterвЂ™s GODFREY takes up the good sword just put down by ODO. (CONTINUED)

GODFREY (CONTвЂ™D) Some say Jerusalem is the very center of the world for asking forgiveness. For myself, I call it here...Now. (вЂњsightingвЂќ the blade) You have lost your wife. BALIAN nods, hollowly. GODFREY (CONTвЂ™D) God has made us men. We must suffer all. GODFREY looks up at the rafters. Wind. Pigeons under the thatched eaves. GODFREY (CONTвЂ™D) I knew your...namesake. (pressing on with it) I knew your mother. BALIAN looks up, knowing everything at once. A hammer in hand. He is the picture of GodfreyвЂ™s murderer. GODFREY (CONTвЂ™D) To be courteous I should say that it was against her objections...that I was the lordвЂ™s brother and she had no choice... (noticing that BALIAN is holding the hammer) But I did not force her. GODFREY lays the sword aside. He will accept what comes. Outside the windows, as the father and son stare at each other, SNOW magically begins to fall hard. BALIAN puts th HAMMER down (GODFREY swallows at this). BALIAN turns to t forge, pumps the bellows, in chaos. GODFREY (CONTвЂ™D) (mervous, aware he is not saying anything properly) I am the Baron of Ibelin. I have a hundred men at arms in Jerusalem. I can use an armorer. (pushing on, brusquely) If you will come with me you will have...a living. And you will have my thanks. There it is. GODFREY is not giving away the shop. (CONTINUED)
Whoever you are, my lord, and whatever you are saying, my place is here.
(gently) What made it your place is now dead. BALIAN shakes his head, with finality. GODFREY (CONTвЂ™D) You will never see me again. If you want anything of me, take it now.
I want nothing. GODFREY, disappointed, but not one to press the point further, nods.
Then I have seen you, and you have seen me, and that is that. I am sorry for your troubles. God protect you. GODFREY goes out from the forge.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE TRACK BY THE FORGE. LATER

text: The party rides out. GODFREY lingers.
It is easy to find Jerusalem. You come to where the men speak Italian, and then continue until they speak something else. We go by Messina. Goodbye. GODFREY turns his horse after his party.
A sword smokes, white-hot, in the coals of the forge. BAL looks up and notices: THE PRIEST, lurking uninvited in th door. He continues to work. (CONTINUED)
The village does not want you. When the old lord is dead they will drive you out. When the bishop is dead, it is certain.
And you take my property.
The Church...
You.

They would have taken you to Jerusalem. Away from all this. I arranged it. (grabs BalianвЂ™s wrist) I swear that you will have no peace as long you stay. No man ever needed a new world more. Imagine your sin and pain erased. All. BALIAN looks up slowly in the firelight. He sees around t priestвЂ™s neck his wifeвЂ™s CRUCIFIX.

And if you Crusade you may relieve your wifeвЂ™s condition in hell. (BALIAN looks at his brother) I put it delicately. She was a suicide. She is in hell. (turns smiling) Though what she does there without a head... BALIAN, the hot metal smoking in his hand, drives the whi hot sword, slowly, through the PRIESTвЂ™s chest, and carries him back onto the live coals of the open forge. The PRIES still alive, looks up in wonder for a long beat, then bur explosively into flame. As the clothes burn away Balian s His wifeвЂ™s crucifix. He grabs it out of the fire. He ba away. COALS have spilled from the forge and the building catching fire. Balian turns and sees: The APPRENTICE. The APPRENTICE turns and runs into the sn  18.

head_text.subj: EXT. A ROAD SOMEWHERE IN FRANCE. DAY

text: GODFREY and his knights are riding. GODFREY reins in, and does the party. GODFREYвЂ™S POV: BALIAN sits his mare atop a small hill. He rides down. BA is hollow-eyed, exhausted in the saddle, his burnt hand wrapped. GODFREY spurs forward.
Have you come to kill me? Even these days, it is not easy. (noticing with real concern BalianвЂ™s distraught condition) What do you want?
Is it true that in Jerusalem I may erase my sins, and those...of my wife. Is it true?
We'll find out together.
IвЂ™ve done murder. Father and son look at each other. Godfrey nods.
Haven't we all. (to the HOSPITALER) Look at his hand.

head_text.subj: EXT. A CAMP BY A RIVER. NIGHT

text: BALIAN is having his hand re-wrapped by FIRUZ. He is give drink by the HOSPITALER.

It is the poppy which grows in the East. I think it is the true lotus that the men of Odysseus ate. It numbs all pain. A burn needs that, and butter. BALIAN, the drug in him, watches as: A falling star glitt and explodes. The men of the camp exclaim at it. (CONTINUED)
HOSPITALER (CONTвЂ™D) (bemused) Perhaps Jerusalem has fallen. BALIAN stares across the fire at GODFREY, who returns his stare. BALIAN cannot keep his eyes open. He sleeps.
A SWORD is thrown into the leaf-mould. BALIAN looks up fr his porridge at: GODFREY, who leans on another sword.
His hand is hurt, my lord.

I have fought two days with an arrow through a testicle. Godfrey swings the flat of his sword at Balian, who, favo his burnt hand parries, clumsily but like lightning and w great force. GODFREY grins: not bad. ODO is watching carefully. BALIAN takes up a вЂњlowвЂќ guard, in terrible he knows what heвЂ™s doing on a dufferвЂ™s level. HeвЂ™s strong, dangerous, a natural, and Godfrey knows it GODFREY (CONTвЂ™D) Never take a low guard. Watch. (He raises the sword above his head) Like this. This guard by the Italians is called la posta di falcone...one strikes from high. Like this. Do it. BALIAN duplicates the posture. GODFREY from the high guar swings low and sweeping and BALIAN parries. The great swo hacks into the dirt. But when Balian strikes at GODFREY...clang! His sword spi away, and ends up falling point down into the earth, the cross hanging sidewards, much like a grave marker. ItвЂ™s obvious: Balian may have some experience, but heвЂ™s not for a knight. ODO takes the sword from Godfrey.
(touches BalianвЂ™s eyes with two fingers) Pay attention. (to Godfrey) I have your leave? (CONTINUED)

GODFREY, sitting in the leaf-litter, eating dried apricot nods gravely. We see ODO and BALIAN circling each other, fighting. Steel clangs. As they practice, others of the p are packing to leave. The SQUIRE oils GodfreyвЂ™s chain m FIRUZ, fastidious, washes his knife and plate at the stre FIRUZ senses something and looks up. GODFREY sets down hi bag of apricots. GODFREYвЂ™S POV A KNIGHT, and then four more KNIGHTS, come out of the tre to the front. They are the equivalent of rich country layabouts out to do a lynching. ODO and Balian stop fight GODFREY mounts and rides over to the newcomers. GODFREYвЂ™S NEPHEW Uncle. GODFREY nods. GODFREYвЂ™S NEPHEW (CONTвЂ™D) You have with you a man, Balian, who killed a priest his brother. I am charged by both my father and the lord bishop to bring him back. The KNIGHTS look at Godfrey, who says nothing. He stares this putrescent nephew calmly.
(riding up to GODFREYвЂ™S
I say he is innocent of the charge. If you say hie is guilty, then we will fight, and God will decide the truth of it.
(leaning drily forward) My German friends is a close student of the law. BALIAN walks up, ready to surrender. Much to his surprise GODFREY winks at him. GODFREYвЂ™S NEPHEW He is a murderer.
(slowly, and very dangerous ) So am I. ArenвЂ™t we all? (CONTINUED)

A half dozen MEN AT ARMS with PIKES come out of the trees the right. GodfreyвЂ™s party is flanked on both sides: CROSSBOWMEN t left, PIKEMEN to the right. And confronted by the knights GODFREY (CONTвЂ™D) Whoever dies here, you will certainly be among them. GODFREYвЂ™S NEPHEW (wrily, looking at the very veteran knight) You are my uncle: I must give you the road. The OPPOSING KNIGHTS unexpectedly wheel away. GODFREY (no new at this) snaps a look left as-- A VOLLEY OF CROSSBOW BOLTS fly out of the trees. The SQUI is struck in the hear and dies instantly. FIRUZ has his m killed beneath him. ODO is shot through the middle of the neck, but he wheels as a PIKEMAN stabs at him grabs the shaft of the PIKE and kills the man holding it. The HOSPITALER also deals with Pikemen (and so does his destrier, a weapon in itself, wh bites a manвЂ™s face off, and kicks another down). GODFREYвЂ™S NEPHEW AND KNIGHTS (having attained the dista mount a charge) wheel and charge the party, taking advant of the confusion following the ambush. GODFREY looks up a them and only now do we see that he has been shot under t arm and into the chest. GODFREY spurs directly at the knights. He kills the man t the left of GODFREYвЂ™S NEPHEW (into whose horse his dest smashes). The HOSPITALER now is with him. HORSES go down: to men have broken the charge; they wheel, looking for enemies. The SERGEANT, as a KNIGHT thunders towards him, swings a and plants it in the earth. The KNIGHT is piked off his rearing horse and the SERGEANT expertly goes forward and daggers him where he lies. He has done this before: a lot In the path there is a general malee. FIRUZ kills two men (The French, in general, are hopelessly outclassed by the Crusaders, and we can see this fact in the white face of GODFREYвЂ™S NEPHEW, whose ambush is coming apart around h and then FIRUZ is shot in the head with a crossbolt. (CONTINUED)

ODO even with a crossbow bolt through his neck and gargli with blood is a serious customer. He runs at and smashes a dismounted knight, and turns and cuts another across th body, armor ripping like linen. The now wounded second KNIGHT, grappling close with ODO, grabs the bolt and twists it. BLOOD spurts everywhere and dropping his sword grabs the manвЂ™s own dagger and kills with it. He staggers a little way, and then falls. A PIKE runs out of the wood with an axe and crushes ODOвЂ™S head two blows and then (as the HOSPITALER, still mounted, whe and runs away. BALIAN, drawing his sword, is being backed among the tree two scrambling CROSSBOWMEN now using short swords. He kil one, and then gets lucky as the other falls. He hacks dow GODFREYвЂ™S NEPHEW emerges through the trees...and he (an equally terrifying, eye-rolling destrier) charges down on Balian. BALIAN stands his ground and-- is shoved aside by ENGLISH SERGEANT. GODFREY rides in between Balian and GODFREYвЂ™S NEPHEW, and confronts his nephew.

(visibly weakening) Thank my brother for his love. GODFREYвЂ™S NEPHEW stares: then turns and rides away. GOD thunders after him, and raising in the saddle (with blood streaming down his side from the wound under his arm), ha down on his nephew with a two-handed stroke that cuts thr his helmet as if it were paper (As he does this though, w see the downward motion of his arm SNAP OFF the shaft of blot, leaving the head of the bolt in his body). GODFREY twists in agony and almost falls out of the saddle. GODFREYвЂ™S NEPHEW'S eyes roll white as he rides on a lit way and then topples from the saddle. GODFREY in agony (m blood streaming through the links of his mail) turns his horse and sees: The ATTACKERS running away, routed. The ENGLISH SERGEANT is kneeling by the KNIGHT knocked down f in the melee by ODO. He has a dagger to the knightвЂ™s th
(almost affably) I am the son of Roger de Cormier. I am accorded the privilege of ransom. GODFREY nods at the ENGLISH SERGEANT who...CUTS THE KNIGH THROAT. (CONTINUED)

(standing up) Nothing better in the world than killing a lord. The HOSPITALER stares with horror at ODO, tries to move h realizes that he is dead. GODFREY, looking at the sun thr the black French trees, has blood bubbling on his lips. H helped from the saddle by the ENGLISH SERGEANT and a CROSSBOWMAN. The HOSPITALER examines him. Both the Hospit and Godfrey, locking eyes, know that the wound is fatal.

The bolt is broken off and cannot be cut out. If your ribs are broken the marrow may enter the blood. You will take a fever and die, or a cyst will form and you will live. You are in the hands of God.

Let me walk. Give me a cup of wine. GODFREY (as he is given the wine) looks sternly at BALIAN GODFREY (CONTвЂ™D) It was not that they had not right to take you. It was the way they asked. Blood comes from GodfreyвЂ™s moth. He wipes it away.
They had right to take me.
(clutching Balian for support) So do I.

head_text.subj: EXT. A GREAT CROSSROADS/PILGRIM CAMP. DAY

text: Where two roads converge in a field, not far from the sea have a great campsite. As our party comes to a juncture o the road we begin to hear a war-song, sung in French). GODFREY is pale, feverish, in agony, barely in the saddle a distance an ANGELIC PRIEST preaches from the back of a wagon: truly and innocently believing what he says.
To kill an infidel, the Pope has said, is not murder. It is the path to heaven. (CONTINUED)
GODFREYвЂ™S PARTY rides through. MUSIC. Each PILGRIM wear some fashion, the cross. BALIAN has never seen such a carnival. The HOSPITALER speaks to an OLD MAN at the head a party of Pilgrims.
Where do you go?
To Jerusalem, brother.
By which road?
Someone knows. God knows.
(to GODFREY) We shall never stop this madness.
It will soon be beyond my concern.

Snow and fire. GODFREY lies on a bed made on the ground. HOSPITALER tends him, washing the wound. BALIAN sits at a distance, watching. GUY DE LUSIGNAN, a splendid knight in tred cross we will associate with extremists in Jerusalem walks up to GodfreyвЂ™s fire with a party of knight-recru
(faux solicitous) No news of reinforcements? If I am in Jerusalem first, as seems-вЂ”вЂ” (smiles) Very likely...I will give the news. GUY looks at Balian.
Who is this?
(for the first time) My son. GUY, thinking that GodfreyвЂ™s pending death has removed his enemies, finds the place unoccupied. (CONTINUED)
Would I had fought you when you were still capable of making bastards. Godfrey chuckles for a long time.
I knew your mother when she was making hers. Fortunately, you could not be one of mine. GUY looks as if he might move on Godfrey: but looks up as sees the Hospitaler, the English sergeant.
(to Godfrey) All will be settled. He goes off with knights.

BELLS ringing in a crumbled belfry. Beyond them: A Mediev port city, a Crusader launching point. Caravels at anchor The Mediterranean winter: whipping wind, a cold blue sea. GODFREY, now near death, rides in a jolting cart, BALIAN rides with him.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE COURTYARD OF THE HOSPITAL OF ST. JOHN. DAY

text: The HOSPITALER meets other HOSPITALERS in clerical habit, gestures to GODFREY. These men come forward. BALIAN watch as his father is carried into the building.

head_text.subj: INT. THE HOSPITAL OF ST. JOHN. DAY

text: The HOSPITALER is praying above the sleeping GODFREY. BAL joins him.
Do not be deceived by his chances. He is in the hands of God.

head_text.subj: EXT. BALCONY AT THE HOSPITAL OF ST. JOHN. DAY

text: GODFREY, lying on a couch where he has been set out for a looks at the harbor.
Balian. Balian joins him. Together the two men look at the harbor (CONTINUED)

GODFREY (CONTвЂ™D) Do you know what lies in the Holy Land? Not what the Church says, but what does lie there? BALIAN shakes his head slowly вЂњnoвЂќ. GODFREY (CONTвЂ™D) A new world. (a beat) A man who in France had not a house is in the Holy Land the master of a city. He who was the master of a city begs in the gutter. There are the end of the world you are not what you were born, but what you have it in yourself to be.
I hope to find forgiveness there. That is all I know. GODFREY is wracked by pain. He needs to cough, but is in much pain. He stares at Balian, and then with great intensity:
Whatever your position, and that I will decide, you are of my house, and that means you will serve the King of Jerusalem.
What might a king ask of a man like me?

This king? A better world than has ever been seen. A kingdom of conscience. A kingdom of heaven. (a beat) Peace instead of war...love instead of hate. Did oyu think that lay at the end of вЂњcrusadeвЂќ? BALIAN shakes his head вЂњnoвЂќ. GODFREY (CONTвЂ™D) (softly) It does. (a beat) There is peace between Christian and Muslims. We live together. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

GODFREY (CONTвЂ™D) Or between Saladin and the King we try. (turns ) Men still go down to the Holy Land for war, however, and war they will have, for all the good kings and fine intentions in the world. (a beat) You will serve the peace, and the King. Swear.
I swear. GODFREY points at a BOWL OF ORANGES.

(points at oranges) Good. Get me one of those. BALIAN does. Godfrey peels the orange. BALIAN allows Godf to put the section of fruit (like the host) into his mout Quite obviously he has never expected that anything on th earth could taste like this. GODFREY (CONTвЂ™D) That is the East. (looks at his son) You are all that survives me. Do not disappoint me.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE PORT OF MESSINA. DAY

text: BALIAN sitting by the wall with the ENGLISH SERGEANT, is fascinated by the sea-trade. (And thereвЂ™s a lot of it: oranges, spices, silks, being unloaded). CRUSADERS are streaming onto ships.

Venetians. Genoans. All the trade of the world. When we took the Holy Land we took the Saracen trading ports. So Italian ships carry silks and spices, and pilgrims if they have money, and Italy becomes rich. (eats sausage off his knife) As the Savior intended. As the sound dies Balian becomes aware of a strange sound Muslims praying. BALIAN looks around and sees: MUSLIM SHIPYARD workers, praying. (CONTINUED)
(astonished, walking forward) What are those men?
(eating) Muslims. Saracens.
They are allowed their prayers?
(shrugs ) If they pay a tax. (translates the prayer) вЂњPraise be to Go, it is proper to praise him.вЂќ

It sounds like...our prayers. The ENGLISH SERGEANT drolly nods: now you're getting it. Destriers ride through the praying Muslims, scattering th GUY comes up on horseback, 20 drunk men with him. He exam Balian insolently. Horse whirls, snapping.
When the King is dead, Jerusalem will be no place for friends to the Muslims and traitors to Christendom like your father. SHOW GUYSвЂ™S MEN. THE IMPOSSIBILITY OF ACTION.
I am Guy de Lusignan. (spits on BALIANвЂ™S tunic: GodfreyвЂ™s livery) Remember that name. And me. He goes to cut Balian across the face with his stick. BAL grabs the stick.
Keep it.
How will you ride, my lord, if you cannot beat the horse? GUY would like to kill Balian on the spot. But his men ha ridden on and the English Sergeant is no joke. (CONTINUED)

I will see you in Jerusalem. GUY rides his horse past the port, his men clattering aft him. The ENGLISH SERGEANT remains. Peering after Guy, then at Balian. Balian, white-knuckled, throws the stick aside.

(goes back to eating) He will be king in Jerusalem one day. BALIAN wipes at his defiled tunic, GodfreyвЂ™s livery, st after Guy. INT. THE вЂњHOSPITALвЂќ OR HOSTEL OF ST. JOHN. NIGHT A fire at the end of the long room. GODFREY, on a couch, dying. A table of candles. A HOSPITALER is writing to GODFREYвЂ™S whispered dictation, which we cannot hear. Ou HOSPITALER comes forward from the deathbed.
(grim, to ENGLISH

Get him. INT. SERVANTвЂ™S SECTION OF THE HOSTEL. NIGHT Balian is asleep on a mat. The ENGLISH SERGEANT kicks him BALIAN looks up: he has been dreading the news that GODFR is dying...and expects it...but does not expect...A WHITE GARMENT, dropped in his lap. SIX HOSPITALERS and the ENGL SERGEANT stand looking at BALIAN, who is very much a peas holding a white cloth.

Put it on. BALIAN looks at the garment, at the man. He stands, alrea shirtless, and puts on the white gown. ENGLISH SERGEANT (CONTвЂ™D) Come with these knights and do not be afraid. I will walk behind.
(no suspicion whatsoever) Come with these knights.  30.
BALIAN, in his white gown, is taken along the hall.

location: THE ROOM WHERE GODFREY IS DYING. CONTINUOUS

text: Balian, entering, confronts: The HOSPITALER. GODFREY is o his feet, supported by two HOSPITALERS.
Get on your knees. BALIAN complies. GODFREY, supported by the monks, comes forward through the gloom. Then he stands by himself abov BALIAN. BALIAN dares for a moment to look up; and then lo down.

(barely able to speak) Be without fear in the face of your enemies. Be brave and upright that God may love thee. Speak the truth, always, even if it leads to your death. Safeguard the helpless, and do no wrong. That is your oath. GODFREY with the last of his strength delivers a blow wit his open hand that nearly knocks Balian sprawling. (There no crap with swords in those days: you got whacked). GODFREY (CONTвЂ™D) And thatвЂ™s so you remember it. As BALIAN recovers, GODFREY is being helped back to his b Balian looks up in wonder.
Rise a knight, and Baron of Ibelin. GODFREY is whispering. BALIAN kneels. GODFREY grips Balia hand. Godfrey is whispering to Balian.
Defend the king. If the king is no more, protect the people. Hands him his (very distinctive) sword.
(softly) You must confess now to Holy God, my lord, not your son. (CONTINUED)
GODFREY nods, weakly: he might differ; but it is time. HOSPITALER (CONTвЂ™D) (whispering) Are you sorry for all your sins?
For all but one. GODFREY nods. OIL is applied to his head. LATIN is spoken The HOSPITALERS kneel. GODFREY slowly makes the sign of t cross; and dies.
Brutal wind. The HOSPITALER walking towards the docks, wi Balian.

I leave now with my order. You will go tomorrow by the Genoan ships. If it is GodвЂ™s will that I die at sea, go to GodfreyвЂ™s house. You will be expected. You will be known. BALIAN nods. The HOSPITALER embraces him. HOSPITALER (CONTвЂ™D) Each day do right. And no wrong. (a beat) God bless you. THE HOSPITALER walks aboard the galley. BALIAN watches. T ENGLISH SERGEANT joins him.
For those who go upon the sea in ships, Mary Mother of God pray for them... As the sound of the WIND rises on sound:

head_text.subj: EXT. THE COAST OF THE KINGDOM OF JERUSALEM. MORNING

text: OPEN ON a beach with wreckage tumbling in the tide race. ENGLISH SERGEANT lies drowned, eyes glazed, his mouth ful sand. The wreckage of a shattered galley lies broken on t sand. Birds are screaming overhead, and pecking at the bo of the drowned. (CONTINUED)

There are knights, priests, great ladies and their servants...and (a RAVEN pecking at his head) Balian, who wakes, coughing. GODFREYвЂ™s SWORD is strapped to his bac RAVEN hops away, cawing. BALIAN wears a simple tunic, hose. He has lost his boots, mail. He gets to his feet and surveys the destruction as sun rises. He approaches one corpse--another--he drives t birds away from several --but they are all dead. Staring to sea he sees: A HORSE tangled in line, maddened with fear. Balian wades out, then swims to the horse. He pulls his knife and cuts free, takes the halter, and leads it out of the water. Holding, calming, the horse, he hobbles it deftly with a piece of line. BALIAN is exhausted, thirsty. He rummages among the wreckage and corpses. (The horse is fighting it hobble throughout). He crouches near a DEAD LADY. He clos her eyes, or tries to, and then snaps loose her purse. He finds a knife on a corpse and sticks it through loops on back of his belt. He finds a lead box containing sodden bread. He stuffs it into his mouth, then spits it out: it impregnated with salt water. He cuts a strap on a case an pulls out... useless womenвЂ™s clothes, a breviary, rosar beads...In the wavewash he finds...a CORKED BOTTLE. As he does, the horse, skittish throughout, snaps its hobble an gallops off down the beach. BALIAN chases after it a little way, then gives up. The h disappears. Balian swigs wine: itвЂ™s not going to do. He water. He looks inland. BALIANвЂ™S POV: A scrap of green in a chasm in the desert rock. The mirag has begun to waver. BALIAN walks into the interior.

BALIAN is walking, sunburnt, desperate to find water. He takes a drink of wine. He comes to the top of a hill and sees: BALIANвЂ™S POV: A WADI. He stumbles, runs, towards the water, and throws himself on the bank, using a cupped hand to shovel water into his mouth. He lies with his cheek in the mud, looking up at t palms rustling overhead. (CONTINUED)

As he lies there he hears, off, a snort, and a slow clopp He lies without moving. The horse he lost on the beach skittishly drinks at the pool, eyeing Balian warily. BALI moves slightly. The horse edges away. Warily Balian tries to move again. The horse watches his every move. Finally, though, the horse comes back to drin and makes his mistake. In two seconds BALIAN has gotten h fingers into the mane and is on the horseвЂ™s back. The h tries to throw him. BALIAN hangs on like a madman, whips his belt, puts it through the halter...and finally, he is riding! He turns the horse and sees: TWO MOUNTED ARABS, staring at him. One (IMAD) is a finely dressed, handsome young man who looks like a scholar. The other is a fantastical Saracen knight with a lance. His helmet drips with chain mail. He wears silk.
(in arabic) That is my horse.
He says, That is his horse.
Why would it be his horse?
Because it is on his land.
I took this horse from the sea. IMAD translates. The Saracen knights says something back.

He says you are a great liar, and that though he will not fight you for the horse, because it is his horse, he will fight you because you are a liar. Further, he will fight you because that is simply what he does.
I have no desire to fight.
Then you must give him the horse and become his slave. He is old- fashioned. (CONTINUED)

No. The SARACEN KNIGHT immediately charges. BALIAN is thrown his rearing horse. The SARACEN KNIGHT drives again with h lance, misses. The lance strikes into the ground and snap he now takes out his bow, and feels for an arorw. BALIAN wildly towards him. The SARACEN KNIGHT keeps his distance trying to nock an arrow. BALIAN slips in the sand.
Fight me fairly.
Why should he?
(just remembering it) I am the Baron of Ibelin.
(translating) He says that the Baron of Ibelin is old. He knew him at Damascus.

I am the new one. This is translated. SARACEN KNIGHT considers. He dismount and draws his sword. BALIAN takes вЂњthe high guardвЂќ as him by godfrey. In the fight, GodfreyвЂ™s good sword snap heavy scimitar. The SARACEN KNIGHT scrambles for the busi end of his broken lance. BALIAN, sword raised over his he runs him down and kills him. IMAD is thrown from his rear horse (BLOOD from the final blow having flown into his horseвЂ™s eyes) and lies stunned on the ground. Staggerin exhaustion, BALIAN approaches IMAD. IMAD, sitting up, hol out his arms in a gesture of surrender. BALIAN digs ravenously in a saddlebag, finds DATES, crams into his mo
You have taken it very well that I have killed your master.
(philosophically) It was the end of his time. Taking it poorly bakes no bread. IMAD is scholarly, awfully well-dressed for a servant, bu Balian has no way to measure this. (CONTINUED)
Take me to Jerusalem.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE DAVID GATE OF JERUSALEM. DAY

text: The massive вЂњDAVID TOWERвЂќ stands above the track. Abo the domes and spires of Jerusalem. It is an impressive si the вЂњcenter of the worldвЂќ, completely walled. BALIAN ride towards the gate, covered with dust.
I will be cloaked in the town if it pleases my lord.
Why?
(lying poorly) I owe money. BALIAN couldnвЂ™t care less. BALIAN and the cloaked IMAD past TOWN GUARDS. We follow through into:

A BOOMING MARKETPLACE. Jerusalem is the crossroads of the world, open to all. Arabs, Jews, Syrians, Byzantine Christians, Europeans, Pilgrims walking barefoot with ash their heads, vast numbers of the mad, naked saints covere with filth. Many, many children. ItвЂ™s almost a city of children. BALIAN and IMAD walk on, leading their horses. master of a Muslim caravan recognizes Imad: begins, shock to speak, to bow; Imad raises a palm and quiets him.
(not having noticed this) Where did Christ die?
(points OS) That is where the Prophet came down from the sky. I am no expert in the other matter.
(almost frantic) I must know where Christ died.
(bemused) I thought he did not. (CONTINUED)
(to a DISREPUTABLE

Where was Christ crucified? The DISREPUTABLE PASSERBY holds out his hand. BALIAN pays a coin. The man points solemnly at A HILL. BALIAN starts up the hill. IMAD, holding the horses, watches him go, bemusedly.
Balian climbs вЂњGolgothaвЂќ with a desperation, as if he find every answer, at the top. A ROBBER (turbaned, ghouli but originally French) holds up: a nail.

It is one of the nails that pierced Our Lord. BALIAN starts to move past. The ROBBER in a flash holds a dagger on BALIAN. BALIAN shoves the man aside (the ROBBER stumbles and falls, losing his knife). BALIAN curs off hi own purse, throws it at the robber and strides on.

That is good. That is Godly. The ROBBER and his FRIENDS scramble and fight for the pur BALIAN comes to the apex of the hill and, taking the cros from beneath his shirt, falls to his knees. He looks uncertain. He lays down the sword, and closing his eyes, clutching the CROSS, prays. He waits for an answer. It is working. We leave him as dust blows around him in the twilight.
STARS have come out. BALIAN still is on his knees but his arms are at his side. A picture of sadness, confusion, defeat.

At cock crow, BALIAN wakes up looks into the rising light needs water. He remembers where he is. He looks out over Jerusalem. He wipes dirt and tears off his face. A man putting himself back together. In one hand he holds the C and in the other the SWORD. He looks around to see if any is observing him, and then quickly scratches a hole and buries the cross, after kissing it. He pats the earth aro it. Scatters stones. (CONTINUED)
(as if to his wife's actual grave) How could you be in hell if you are in my heart? He puts himself together.
Goodbye. Heads down the hill.

head_text.subj: EXT. A STREET IN JERUSALEM. MOMENTS LATER

text: IMAD is asleep, the reins of the horses wrapped around hi arm. BALIAN crouches, and wakes Imad.
Did you find what you wanted?
Take the better horse and be about your business.
It is your prize of war. I was the servant of the man you killed. I am your prisoner. Your slave, should you wish.
I have been a slave, or very near to one. I will never keep one nor suffer any to be kept. Go. IMAD looks at Balian with admiration. Not overcooked: he accepts it.
(mounting) You killed a very great cavalier among the Moslems. His name was Mummad al Fais.
(seriously) I will pray for him.
Your quality will be known among your enemies before ever you meet them. (CONTINUED)
IMAD raising a palm rides out. BALIAN looks around at the Holy City. Nearby: a BAKERвЂ™S STALL. Balian is hungry, but feeling belt, realizes that he gave his purse away. He moves on through the city.

head_text.subj: EXT. A SQUARE IN JERUSALEM. MORNING

text: TWO MEN in the same livery Balian wears, lean against a w outside a wine-shop, checking out the town, and then...something else.
BALIAN, wearing tattered Ibelin livery, Godfrey's unmistakable sword strapped to his back, moves through th crowded square.
BALIAN pays a penny to drink at a dirty, crowded, PILGRIM FOUNTAIN, from an iron cup on a chain. One of GODFREYвЂ™S MEN speaks to the other, who departs.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE SQUARE IN JERUSALEM. LATER

text: BALIAN is sitting on the ground, eating dates hungrily fr wrap of cloth. A shadow falls across him. He looks up to SIX OF GODFREYвЂ™S MEN. Sergeant. All in livery. BALIAN draws his sword. ALAMARIC comes forward. Godfrey's number one, top-sergeant of forty-odd, a man with some education.
Since you wear GodfreyвЂ™s livery, you must know him.
Yes.
A man my size.
No. Taller.
Indeed. And with green eyes, notoriously. (CONTINUED)
(thinking, remembering) Blue. GODFREYвЂ™S MEN go onto their knees, and in turn take Bal hand, kissing it. Almaric takes the sword.

Come with us. My lord. EXT./INT. GODFREYвЂ™S HOUSE IN JERUSALEM ESTABLISH GODFREYвЂ™S GRATED DOOR. AlmaricвЂ™s first poun it. BALIAN moves like a sleepwalker into the COURTYARD. O could no imagine anything greener or more beautiful Falli water. Fruit trees. Birds. We see (as he sees) that Godfr house (to one side of the courtyard) is a bit like a firehouse: stables below (with a separate walled yard). T sergeants (now staring out of windows) sleep above. WOMEN THE HOUSE come forward, veiled, and gently guide BALIAN w he needs to go.

head_text.subj: INT. A LITTLE ROOM IN THE HOUSE. MOMENTS LATER

text: In a dreamlike sequence Balian, standing naked in a coppe bowl, is bathed with sea-sponges by the girls. INT. GODFREYвЂ™S BEDROOM. AFTERNOON BALIAN is sleeping on silks, in a breeze, in the shadow o window-lattice. He wakes, feels the fabric. He sees: a bo of ROSEWATER. He drinks it uncertainly, and then tries to the petals. SERVANT-GIRLS flee, giggling. INT. BALIANвЂ™S HOUSE. MORNING BALIAN, wearing a silk tunic, explores the rooms, nodding the people who stare at him, and bow. Bowed at in the kitchens, he nervously escapes into the STABLES.
(eating, to alarmed
He may be mad.
A clumsy use of a hoof-pick. A horse screams. OPEN UP ON: BEAUTIFUL WARHORSE is shying from both a YOUNG SERGEANT a an ARAB BLACKSMITH. (CONTINUED)
BALIAN comes in and grabs the horse by the halter. With g gentle force. Forearm braced along the head. The horse settles down.
You've hurt him. The YOUNG SERGEANT and the ARAB BLACKSMITH back away. BAL slowly gets loops of line around the frightened horseвЂ™s and back legs, stable-boys helping.

head_text.subj: EXT. GALLERY ABOVE THE STABLE COURTYARD. LATER

text: ALMARIC is staring dubiously out into the yard.

Will you look at that. The HOSPITALER comes forward out of the gloom, and looks down, smiling, through lattice. Now in Jerusalem the Hospitaler is not in his stained travel kit, but resplend looking more the priest, though in armor. The Hospitaler looks like God.

BALIAN with gentleness and intensity is shoeing the horse is shirtless and covered with sweat. Frightened Arab STABLEHANDS stare at him, hand him what he needs. BALIAN down the hoof just done, and (as hoofbeats sound)looks ar as A SURF OF DOGS, WHIPPETS, flood into the courtyard. Th horse, eyes rolling white, nearly breaks its back against restraints. BALIAN, kicking at the snarling dogs, charges into the courtyard, hammer in his hand.

Who is the fool with these dogs? He hurls the hammer aside in anger (it sparks off the bri Stops and stares, stunned at: A beautiful woman sits side saddle on a palfrey. She wears riding silks, and a turban. The sun behind her. SIBYLLA. She is as startled as Balian. BALIAN stares at h open-mouthed.
The fool with the dogs is the Princess of Jerusalem. BALIAN perhaps resentfully, bows, serf-low, the only thin knows how to do in the circumstances. (CONTINUED)
SIBYLLA rides around him. HorseвЂ™s hooves, circling him. watches the horseвЂ™s hooves out of the former of his eye dogs still foam around.

Will you give me a cup of water? BALIAN goes to the bucket. He takes out the ladle. Shakes It doesn't look to clean. But he fills it anyway and walk the quivering water to the still-mounted Sibylla. She tak the water, eyes locked on BalianвЂ™s, and drinks. She fin and hands him the ladle.
It is a hot day.
Yes.
I thank you for the drink.
Yes. He canвЂ™t quite figure out why he has been given her handkerchief with the ladle. He tries to return it and is ignored.

If in the course of your work you should see Balian, the son of Godfrey, who is now come from France...tell him that Sibylla called...that I bless his fatherвЂ™s name...and that I wept at the news. SIBYLLA turns horse and gallops out, her dogs tumbling af her. BALIAN goes to the gate and in deep confusion stares afte the splendid figure caroming down the street, scattering merchants like pigeons. AMALRIC has come down from the gallery and is looking wit concern at the potential madman. The HOSPITALER is smilin BALIAN nods at him: Whoa.
I imagine you will become better at dealing with the nobility. Bow no more to equals, my lord. (CONTINUED)

(gently to agitated stableboys) When I am working a horse keep the gates shut. Thank you. BALIAN turns and sees the Hospitaler. The Hospitaler embr him. INT. BALIANвЂ™S HOUSE, BEDROOM. DAY The HOSPITALER is eating yogurt, beautiful fruit. Balian being dressed behind a screen.
How find you Jerusalem?
God does not speak to me. Not even on the hill where Christ died. I am outside GodвЂ™s grace.
I have not heard that.
At any rate, I have lost my religion. BALIAN emerges from behind the screen. He is in armor: th Baron of Ibelin: a knight.

(softly, seeing Godfrey in him) No matter. (as BalianвЂ™s sword is belted on) I put no stock in вЂњreligionвЂќ. BALIAN is surprised. This man has holy orders. HOSPITALER (CONTвЂ™D) By the word вЂњreligionвЂќ I have seen the lunacy of fanatics of every denomination be called the will of God. I have seen too much religion in the eyes of too many murderers. Holiness is in right action, and courage in behalf of those who cannot defend themselves. Goodness, what God desires, is here... (CONTINUED)

With two fingers he touches BalianвЂ™s forehead, and then hear. HOSPITALER (CONTвЂ™D) And here. By what you decide to do every day you will be a good man or not. Come. (a beat) Did you know that you are famous?

head_text.subj: EXT. A STREET IN JERUSALEM. LATER

text: BALIAN and the HOSPITALER ride through the town. BALIAN i his armor. PEOPLE bow. We hear whispers. PEOPLE (original from all nations, from Viking lands to the Horn of Africa stare at BALIAN. Some people follow him through the stree Boys tumbling after. Balian is alarmed at the attention f the street, the BOYS now running beside his horse. BALIAN looks unnerved and not very happy about this. He s Two TEMPLARS, bearded Christian fanatics, their hands tie behind them, ropes around their necks.

(explaining) The King has made a peace with Saladin these six years. He holds Jerusalem as a place for prayer for all faiths, as the Saracens did before we came. These men killed Arabs. Spectator TEMPLARS (kept back by pikemen wearing the King livery) roar objections; but still the signal is given. T men are hoisted; hang.
So they are dying for what the Pope and every priest in Europe would command them to do.

(simply) Yes. But not Christ, I think. Nor this king. INT. OUTSIDE TIBERIASвЂ™ ROOMS AT THE PALACE. DAY VOICES raised in Arabic and English. BALIAN, aware of but helplessly disinterested in the argument, off, stands inspecting a scale model of the city and walls of Jerusal He frowns at some problems...moves a section of the wall. moves it back...but not happily. (CONTINUED)
(simply) That should be there. He looks as if heвЂ™s going to go see someone about it. T HOSPITALER watches.
(with great force and simplicity) ThatвЂ™s wrong. BALIAN now crouches to look at a scale model of a SIEGE ENGINE. A SECRETARY stares at him. Balian backs off.
(shouting) Who says I raid? MOVE INSIDE THE ROOM. TIBERIAS, a plain ferocious knight and noble of fifty-odd leans over his table.
(shouting) This witness, all Jerusalem, holy God, and me. REYNALD OF CHATILLON, a magnificent old brigand with a handlebar moustache, is on the carpet. He looks at a MUSL GRANDEE.
This witness, if you call him that, is a Saracen. He lies.
There will come a day, Reynald of Chatillon, when you are not protected by your title.
Oh? When will that be? (royally amused) Alert me, Tiberias, when men are equal, and the Kingdom of Heaven has arrived.
(pointing down into the square) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
Those Templars have been hung for a raid I am sure you commanded.
Prove it, Tiberias. I will wait at Kerak till you do.
The king will take your castle of Kerak, Reynald.
I hold Kerak through France and my wife. Not this king. Try to take it, Tiberias. I will be there. TIBERIAS stares with frustration. REYNALD exits. The MUSL GRANDEE starts shouting in Arabic.
(to business) I cannot protect your caravans unless you agree to be escorted by our soldiers.
I trade to make money. Not to offend God by associating with Christians. TIBERIAS holds out GOLD.
But you will take Christian gold, of course. The GRANDEE, of course, does, instantly.
You are an ignorant and difficult bastard.
(smugly ) Who is ignorant who knows God? TIBERIAS exhaustedly waves the man out. The MUSLIM GRANDE goes, starchily. TIBERIAS, face in hands, sits at his wor table.
My lord. (CONTINUED)
TIBERIAS looks up and sees: BALIAN. TIBERIAS gets up and walks nearer the table with the model. He holds out both hands and Balian, after a moment of uncertainty, takes th
It is true. (remarking resemblance) You are your fatherвЂ™s son. He was my friend. I am yours. (a beat) Godfrey dead...It could have come at a better time.
He has been examining your model.
An engineer? BALIAN nods, peering at the model, almost unable to help himself, and Tiberias notices.
It was shouted in the streets this morning that you killed a great lord of Syria.
I was fortunate.
Saladin himself has written to say your fight was no breach of the peace. That you had a cause. (a beat) What know you of Saladin?
That he is the King of the Saracens, and surrounds this kingdom.

Indeed he does. He has two hundred thousand men at Damascus alone. He might win a war if he goes to war and he is daily given cause for war by the Templars, by fanatics newly from Europe, and by bastards like Reynald. Here from this room I keep the peace, so far as it may be kept. I begin sometimes to wonder if itвЂ™s worth the trouble. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
But Saladin and the king between them would make... (exhaustedly) --.a вЂњbetter worldвЂќ. (a beat, smiling) What did your father tell you of your obligations?
That I was to be a good knight. TIBERIAS at first smiles. Then looks BALIAN closely in th eye.
I pray the world and Jerusalem can accommodate such a rarity as a perfect knight. (a beat) Have you dined?

head_text.subj: INT. THE GREAT HALL OF THE PALACE. NIGHT

text: In a great hall under a long second-story gallery A DININ TABLE. TIBERIAS, careworn, is eating slowly. BALIAN is nervous, picking at food. He looks up as two figures come into the room: GUY and SIBYLLA. Sibylla holds GuyвЂ™s arm. BALIAN looks down at his plate seats his wife; and then sits across from Balian and star at him. Drunk, and pouring wine from a jug.
You sit at my table? BALIAN and GUY stare at each other.
It is the kingвЂ™s table. So I am told.

It is. I have not seen a king at it for some years. (stares at Balian, drinks wine) Well. However far you rise we shall always remember the docks. Eh? (rising) I wonвЂ™t eat. I am finicky about company. In France (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

(points at Balian) This could not inherit. But here there are no civilized rules. He rises to leave. GUY and TIBERIAS stare at each other, inch from drawing daggers. SIBYLLA sits her face unchange BALIAN steals a look at SIBYLLA, who catches him at it: a world is said though her face does not change.
I have business in the East. My wife does not lament at my absences. That is either the best of wives (kisses the top of SibyllaвЂ™s head) Or the very, very, worst. (goes)
Do you go to meet Reynald? GUY turns at the door.

(openly lying, and mocking Tiberias) No, my lord. He is in disfavor. I am a member of this court. Why should I make league with that...trouble-maker. He upends his cup. Wine like blood on the stones. Then he drops the cup and leaves. No one can think of anything to say. Sibylla turns hostess and as if this has not happene
(to BALIAN) We will ride together. And you will tell me about France and what is and is not the fashion there now. BALIAN looks, to say the least, unequal to the job.
(drily) Are you married?
My wife is dead. (CONTINUED)
(dry) You must be found another.
When I am ready I imagine I will find her myself. She smiles at his abruptness. But has reason (Guy) to loo careworn. She looks seriously at Balian, who is now eatin
(murmuring) The king. All stand quietly. The KING moves along through the shado attended. A white, masked, figure on the gallery above.
(brokenly, careworn, and now to himself) The king. All stand. The KING disappears from the gallery. An Equer comes forward and whispers in TIBERIASвЂ™ ear.
The King would see Godfrey's son.
(smiles) I will take him.
Falling water. The palace is full of shadows, whispers, a desert Elsinore. BALIAN, walking with SIBYLLA, looks arou warily. The dinner continues beyond an archway (TIBERIAS talking business).
I spoke without knowing who you were.
(running her fingers over the plants) Would knowing who I am make any difference to the fact that I was wrong? (CONTINUED)
No.
I was wrong. I am sorry. Sibylla walks lightly along.
I knew who you were. ItвЂ™s unmistakable. I loved your father. I shall love you. BALIAN trips on a stone. Sibylla smiles.
Do you fear being with me?
Yes. SIBYLLA looks pleased. It is as it should be. She walks around the fountain.
A woman in my place has two faces. One for the world, and one which she wears in privacy.
I have never had more than one face.
That will change with your new position.
I do not think so. Sibylla, jolted, looks back at him with great interest.
Then with you, I will be only Sibylla. A slight sound. A SERVANT susses out the fairly dangerous sexual situation and disappears behind a pillar.
Tiberias thinks me unpredictable. I am unpredictable. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
(smiles) Come. She takes BALIANвЂ™s hand. Not grandly. Like a girl.

head_text.subj: INT. A CORRIDOR IN THE PALACE. MOMENTS LATER

text: BALIAN and SIBYLLA have come to the kingвЂ™s door, which guarded.
You do not come in?

No. (with genuine respect) I cannot. She lets go of his hand and goes off down the corridor. A the end she opens a door: a fall of light. She goes throu the door, leaving the door open. Balian stares at the ope door; then looks at the door to the kingвЂ™s chambers. Th doors are swung open. INT. THE KINGвЂ™S APARTMENTS. NIGHT BALIAN enters the room. It is lit by oil-lamps. Silks and tapestries but it is still a working room--papers and scr -books. A great map. The KING sits in a chair before the window, his back to Balian. Before him, Jerusalem and the desert stars.
(easily, but lonely) I warn you before I turn: I wear a mask. BALIAN stands staring in lamplight. We see as he sees; on the kingвЂ™s swaddled hands.

Do not kneel. I loved your father. I am glad to know his son. He turns. What he wears is the most beautiful mas imagina (possibly representing the face that once was), hammered silver, catching light.
The man you killed in the desert, though a Saracen, was my fatherвЂ™s friend. He taught me to hawk when I was a boy. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

He taught me to shoot arrows from horseback as the Saracens do. He was there when my arm was pinched and it was he, not my fatherвЂ™s physicians, who noticed that I felt no pain. He wept when he gave my father the news. (his eyes expressive in the mask) I am a leper. This disease, the Saracens say, is GodвЂ™s vengeance against the vanity of our kingdom. As wretched as I am here, the Arabs say after their book, the chastisement that awaits me in hell is more severe and lasting. (a wry beat) If it is true, I call it unfair. BALIAN may know that this man wants a friend: but heвЂ™s to act expect as if he is with a king-- whose eyes die a little when he sees that Balian averts his own eyes The K is condemned to be lonely. Condemned also to be a king.
Wine. The SERVANT pours two cups. Very careful about which cup which. Balian takes his own. The king drinks with swaddled hands sits at a table with a CHESS-SET.

Do you play? BALIAN shakes his head. A CRUSE CHESSPIECE: A PAWN. It is triangle of ivory. It is touched by an artfully, even beautifully, bandaged hand. BALIAN looks at the BOARD. Dimension after dimension of room for error.
It is the world. We see the young kingвЂ™s masked face.
Each move can be the death of you. (on the CRUDE PAWN) Do anything except remain in your starting place and you cannot be sure of your end. Were you sure once of your end? (CONTINUED)
I was.
What was it?
To be buried a hundred yards from where I was born.
And now?
Now I am in Jerusalem and look upon a king.

A King may move a man...a father may claim a son...a man may move himself...and then the man begins his own game. Remember howsoever you are played, or by whom, that your soul is in your keeping. Even though those who presume to play you be kings. Remember. (the mask, in firelight, raises) When you answer to God you cannot say вЂњI was told it was thusвЂќ, or that virtue вЂњwas not the fashion of my timesвЂќ. Remember. BALIAN stares at a PAWN. Flickering light. He looks up.
I will. BALIAN stares at the king. THE KING slides a paper toward Balian, with a drawing on it (basically it is pretty much along the ideas that Balian is thinking) - i.e it has the shape of a cross.
It is a fortification.
(nods ) I have drawn it. What do you think of it? (CONTINUED)
I have thought, many times, that a castle should be in the shape of a cross. (A stick of charcoal on the table.) May I? THE KING nods, smiling.
Improve it.

A cross...or a star. Like this. (draws a вЂњstar fortвЂќ) That way, not part of a fortress may be approached without being exposed to fire from another part. 54. THE KING smiles, and furls the paper. He has made the tes

You will go to your house of Ibelin, and protect the pilgrim road. Protect in particular the Jews and the Muslims. (defiant: the Mask comes up) All are welcome in Jerusalem. Not because it is expedient, but because it is right. (a beat: drinks off his cup) Protect the helpless. BALIAN takes it seriously.
And when one day I am helpless...perhaps you will protect me. (a beat) You may go. BALIAN looks up The glittering mask. Balian nods, goes ou The KING returns to his lonely chair by the window.
BALIAN comes out of the kingвЂ™s apartments, and looks do hall. (CONTINUED)

SIBYLLAвЂ™S DOOR still stands open, light falling into th hall. Balian might well have walked towards the door, but a BOY (SibyllaвЂ™s son) is standing in the hall, staring at Bal expressionlessly. BALIAN raises his hand. The BOY backs a and disappears into his room. A LEAD EQUESTRIAN KNIGHT on floor. BALIAN picks it up, weighs it in his hand. The BOY peeps around the corner again. BALIAN smiles experimental The BOY disappears. BALIAN fixes the soldier, bending a b bit back into place, and places the LEAD KNIGHT on the ed of a balustrade. He goes.

head_text.subj: EXT. A BARRACKS COURTYARD IN THE PALACE. MORNING

text: The king has charged you with your tasks. You keep the peace. (glaring at the men--of Ibelin, and other houses) To break the peace, to rob Saracen, Jew or Christian, is death on the instant. Do you understand. BALIAN nods. His men nod, perhaps more reluctantly.
Ibelin.
That shithole.
Ssh. TIBERIAS comes up to BALIAN, and privately.
Be gone to Ibelin. Not least before the princess Sibylla does take you...вЂќridingвЂќ. TIBERIAS smiles, and hands BALIAN some rolled parchments bound with ribbon.
These are my plans of the city defenses. (Balian hesitates respectfully) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
Better them if you can. I defend Jerusalem, not my reputation. BALIAN nods respectfully. TIBERIAS smiles.

JEWS by a campfire stand and bow as BALIAN, cloaked, ride past with forty of his mounted men, also cloaked. They ar very much policemen on patrol. FACES of the pilgrims: the young, the old. They ride on, past more CHRISTIAN PILGRIM trudging towards the city -- the mad, the penitent, the merely curious, the barely alive. A NAKED MAN crawls...dr himself along, mumbling. BALIAN looks at him and spurs on

location: A CAMP BY THE PILGRIM ROAD. TWILIGHT

text: Cold men by a fire (still unsure of Balian). A SERGEANT h out a plate of boiled wheat. BALIAN takes it and eats wit his fingers. He is aware of the silence and discomfort an plain curiosity of his men. Some are peering at him. BALI puts down his plate, and stands.
I am not my father. His men, who have been thinking just this, look at each other.
But I will do my best. BALIAN walks off alone. He sees: A PROCESSION OF CHILDREN singing, on their way to Jerusalem.
They ride into show, reining in.
There, my lord. BALIAN rides a little forward.
Ibelin. BALIANвЂ™S POV: IBELIN. A faintly green valley floor, an oasis, a fort th would best be called a вЂњcasbahвЂќ. A village around it.  57.

Establish Ibelin as Balian and his party ride in. WOMEN w buckets hung on poles are carrying water towards the dry MELON FIELDS. The population consists of Jews, Saracens, Arab Christians. The place is desperately poor.
(embarrassed) Your father was important. His lands were not. But to Balian it might as well be paradise.

I have no importance. It will suit me just fine. Entering the WALLED CASBAH area, BALIAN and his party dismount. PEOPLE stand and stare, keeping their distance. ARAB goes on his knees before BALIAN and Balian courteous helps him up. The ARAB is stunned. BALIAN walks on, removing his gloves, beating the dust ou his surcoat. At the steps of the house he stops: An OLD HOUSEMAN in a skullcap is staring at him, open mouth toothless. BALIAN climbs the stairs. The two men look at each other. OLD HOUSEMAN searches BalianвЂ™s face.

Yes? He plucks at the ensign on his breast. The OLD HOUSEMAN smiles, and kisses both of BalianвЂ™s cheeks. The PEOPLE are murmuring, respectfully. BALIAN, from the steps of his house, takes it all in. HOR are watering.

The OLD HOUSEMAN pads ahead through the dark, sunsplinter rooms. Some ruinous furniture, cushions. ALMARIC watches BALIAN warily (still not knowing this guy) as BALIAN take his house. The OLD HOUSEMAN runs up with a slopping cup o wine. BALIAN takes it, sips, and keeps walking. He comes the back of the house, where arched openings give onto th oasis, a green and saline-looking pool under blowing palm (CONTINUED)

Twilight is coming on. Balian hears, of all things, chick Along an ell of the house there are chicken coops. AN ARAB GIRL, collecting eggs. She turns, sensing that sh being stared at. She is veiled across. She continues to t eggs from beneath the hens. BALIAN, caught in a memory, dissolves in it. We know as he catches his breath that he alive again, he could have a life here.
My lord, this is a poor and dusty place.
Is it.
BALIAN and ALMARIC, chased by a horde of children and som more restrained adults, are walking though the farm area. Poor cultivation, dust blowing from cracked dikes.
We've got Jews...different types of Jews, I think...Fatmid Muslims, and the other... BALIAN, moving along, jumps up on a dike, and continues, children chasing along.
Easter Christians and Roman... BALIAN stops, windblown, and smiles.
But mainly, we have no water.
Slightly up from the pool, we see that the pool is fed by marshy trickle. BALIAN crouches, looking at the lie of th land.

PEASANTS are digging, already five or six feet down in th dampish ground. BALIAN is with them in the middle of the using a heavy iron pole to slam deep into the earth...bot вЂњsoundingвЂќ and loosening. PEASANTS are taking the damp earth and immediately formin bricks with it.  59.

The well is deeper. Now the walls are shored up with timb BALIAN slams and slams with his iron bar. The men are ank deep in seepage, the shoveled earth goes up in leather buckets on ropes. Suddenly, as BALIAN leans exhausted... The water level rises evenly. The diggers look at each ot
(exhausted) Right. Stone the well. As he comes up from the well, the PEOPLE (Jews, Christian Saracens) are exultant--and so is BALIAN, at first shy, a then smiling hugely.

MONTAGE. Irrigation ditches being dug while Balian superv and pitches in. Clay troughs and pipes being manufactured molded, and then set in a great kiln. WOMEN working leath into what may be buckets. BALIAN moves through it all. He crouches with skll-capped ARAB CARPENTERS. He draws in the dirt with a stick while men nod.
They are making lords different in France from when I was there.
Torches are lit on the rough battlements. BALIAN stares o at the desert, satisfied, in his home. On the road, a solitary pilgrim proceeds to Jerusalem on his knees.

A commotion among the people. They run towards the center some activity. What they see there is wonderful. CARPENTE MEN-AT-ARMS, various helpers, and BALIAN, using brute strength, as well as a rope passing through pulley on a p are setting upright...a giant WATERWHEEL.
Brace it, brace it. Almaric, tell them to brace it! (CONTINUED)

Almaric does. BALIAN makes sure the wheel is secure. He b away from the work and sees that... An ARAB is staring pen mouthed at something OS. More PEAS stare, and then go to their knees. BALIAN turns and sees: WHIPPETS. They course around in a pack. He looks up and s SIBYLLA, mounted. She is veiled and with a guard of Turcopole lancers. SIBY rides forward through whirling dust and light. She wears sort of burnoose all her face but her eyes covered with s BALIAN walks towards her, through wind, and, without rega to his filthiness, bows. Not particularly courtly. SIBYLLA removes her veil, staring at him.
I am on my way to Cana. That is where Jesus changed water to wine. A better trick would to be to change you to a nobleman.

In France I used to think that with a few yards of silk I could make an aristocrat of any man, so long as he was useless. Sibylla laughs delightedly. BALIAN smiles. SERVANTS rush her considerable, fantastical baggage-train forward through the casbah gates.
It seems that I ask your hospitality.
(holding her bridle) It is given. Sibylla smiles and rides through the gates.

head_text.subj: EXT. A ROOM AT IBELIN. DAY

text: SERVANTS attend SIBYLLA. They take her cloak, her вЂњturb she reveals and drops her hair. Her вЂњmaskвЂќ of office be entirely in place. A servant removes SIBYLLAвЂ™s small velvet shoes. A servant brushes her hair as another remov her riding gear. A SERVANT unpacks a lead-lined box of...snow, and puts it into a silver goblet. Sibylla drin  61.

head_text.subj: EXT. A POOL BEHIND THE CASBAH AT IBELIN. DAY

text: SIBYLLA, now in loose Arab muslin, comes along the galler SERVANTS with her. She has her silver goblet. SIBYLLA dri and looks at Balian. No dialog necessary. She goes to the pool, steps barefoot into it, and washes. Her wrists. Bal looks around at the desert. Sibylla bends forward as a servant pours water over her hair. She moves forward thro the water, the muslin wet, and hands Balian her cup. She wrings the end of her muslin wrap, and washes the dust fr BalianвЂ™s face. He catches her wrist, meaning: donвЂ™t. are watching.
(smiling, and continuing to wash his face) This isnвЂ™t adultery, itвЂ™s washing. BALIAN looks not so much embarrassed, as embarrassed at b embarrassed.
But if it were adultery, which (she wipes his face) it isnвЂ™t, the Commandments are not for persons in our positions. They are for others.
(gruffly, remembering that he ought to think about this) Did they give you something to eat?

(a tucked smiles as she kicks through the pool) Yes. They вЂњgave me something to eatвЂќ. Out of shot, with Balian staring after her. Picked up, sh wades into the green, saline, pool, under the palms, hold up her dress. SheвЂ™s no princess, just a girl kicking th the water. She stops and looks into the desert. Rippling wind. Beyond palms, mirages. SIBYLLA cocks her head, wait to hear if Balian comes up behind her. He has not. She looks around and sees: BALIAN is gone. She smiles, and kicks on through the wate  62.

head_text.subj: INT. THE HOUSE AT IBELIN. AFTERNOON

text: SIBYLLA watches from the roof terrace as SIBYLLAвЂ™S POV: Within a crowd of exultant peasants THE WATERWHEEL is lif (fairly easily now) on its long axle and is fitted into i frame above the new well.
BALIAN working. BALIAN, intense, turns the wheel by raw force, and watches...buckets come up, full of water. he n and lets the wheel drop. MONTAGE details of the gearing b assembled.
SIBYLLA, watching Balian, leaning against the stones, see to have come to some decision. Terrible heat.
I think we are looking at the one man in the world who is not like another. The Maidservant lays a damp cloth across her eyes.
On the contrary, he is common, my lady. Your husband Guy is a man. SIBYLLA laughs, the cloth over her eyes. She looks like Justice.
MONTAGE the completion of the waterwheel, and its operati Water gushes through pipes into troughs into ditches, and paddies begin to flood, the soil darkening.
Among his dancing subjects, and grinning men-at-arms (ALM even essays to slap his back), BALIAN is lost in thought of...as he looks back at his house...Sibylla, who stands the roof, watching.

head_text.subj: INT. THE GREAT ROOM AT IBELIN. EVENING

text: BALIAN is drawing. SIBYLLA watches him from behind a gauz curtain. (CONTINUED)
Balian dips his pen in ink. Draws, blots, draws. SIBYLLA comes behind Balian and looks over his shoulder. BALIAN becomes aware of her.
You have a guest. BALIAN looks at her boldly.
I am aware. That I have a guest. SIBYLLA lowers her eyes and changes the subject.
Is this the...вЂќworkвЂќ...you did in France? What I saw today?
In my work in France the only thing that was mine was the quality. She looks at his drawings.
These are the walls of Jerusalem. You have changed the David Gate.
Yes. It ought to be changed. It is...impractical.

Eleven hundred and fifty years ago, Jesus Christ rode through it on a donkey. (raises palms drolly) In Jerusalem, as it was, it shall be. Jerusalem is not about what is practical. To say...the least. BALIAN smiles. He likes this woman. Sibylla and Balian lo at each other. Neither are smiling now. At the moment of intolerable sexual tension, a bell rings at the end of th room. BALIAN looks and sees SIBYLLAвЂ™S SERVANTS (includi scandalized MAIDSERVANT) laying out a meal. He moves with Sibylla towards the low table. They sit on cushions. A fi burns at the end of the room. Sibylla eats, with knife an fingers, licking her fingers, drinking wine. (No silverwa doesnвЂ™t mean no manners). Sibylla looks up and sees Bal staring at her. (CONTINUED)
What?
It seems years since I have seens a woman eat.
The Hospitaler told me what occurred in France. BALIAN looks up.
(tearing flat bread) Had he not told me, I would have had him tortured. (they both laugh, but then seriously: ) You loved her.
Yes. (a beat) I did. Very much. She was melancholy. I loved her. Quietly, they eat. The drapes blow, the candles flare.
I watches you today. You have been given a patch of dust and it almost seems you will build a new Jerusalem here.
It is my house. What would I be if I did not make it better? Sibylla plays with her glass. She looks carefully at Bali And then, as if caught staring, looks chaotically down.

location: A GALLERY AT IBELIN. DEEP TWILIGHT

text: SIBYLLA and BALIAN are walking. As BALIAN looks at her, t is a MUSLIM CALL TO PRAYER...the last of the day.
(off the prayer) They try to be one: one heart, one morality. One passion. They try to do without our infinite complications. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
(a beat) Their prophet says вЂњsubmitвЂќ. Jesus said вЂњdecideвЂќ. On вЂњdecideвЂќ she looks directly at Balian, and is quit clearly in love with him.
(to change the subject) Do you pray?
I pray that I may be equal to what has been asked of me. To what has been given me.
